awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Adversarial Machine Learning for Structured Prediction
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering

por.por_cntn:
This project developed new machine learning methods for predicting multiple variables that are interrelated due to properties of the data distribution or characteristics of the evaluation metric. Existing methods typically suffer either from computational intractability (i.e., running times that are exponential complexity) or from predictive inconsistency (i.e., the inability to learn the optimal predictor even when provided an infinite amount of training data). It used tools from game theory and distributionally-robust estimation to cast the prediction task as a game between a predictor seeking to minimize some evaluation/loss measure, and an adversary seeking to maximize the predictor's loss while still being similar to training data samples. A noteworthy result is learning bipartite matches (e.g., assigning N individuals to N jobs). Existing probabilistic methods based on random fields require exponential time to normalize a probability distribution over all matches, while maximum margin methods lack consistency guarantees. This project developed a method that provided consistency guarantees with polynomial time complexity for inference. Beyond this, the project showed that probabilistic graphical models can generally be estimated using this same robust approach with only a modest (and not exponential!) increase in time complexity. It also developed new methods for harder learning problems (e.g., predicting graph cuts, three-dimensional matchings, and robust Markovian decision making) for which polynomial time complexity appears entirely out of reach. In terms of practical impact, the methods of this project were also applied to fair machine learning problems by imposing fairness constraints on the "predictor player" in the game formulation. This leads to new parametric models (see attached images) for making fair predictions under various notions of fairness, and the potential to expand fairness-aware inductive decision-making to the range of structured prediction tasks investigated more broadly in this project.

Seven PhD students supported by this research successfully defended their theses and have taken positions in industry or academia. Code produced by the project has been released to the public. The methods and insights developed by the project provide helpful guidance for machine learning practicioners in high-stakes domains with structured variables or performance measures in which computational efficiency and predictive consistency are both needed. Incorporating fairness constraints into the prediction game provides a principled approach for resolving ambiguity that exists when making fairneess aware predictors and provides individual fairness based on the smoothness of the resulting parametric predictors.
